question: 1 (d)
sols_html:
Our goal is to find f(3). Since f(x) is continuous we know that \(f(3) = \lim_{x \to 3} f(x)\) and thus finding f(3) amounts to finding the limit.

Using the limit laws we have

\[\begin{aligned} 1 = \lim_{x \to 3} (xf(x) + g(x)) = \lim_{x \to 3} x \lim_{x \to 3} f(x) + \lim_{x \to 3} g(x).\end{aligned}\]

Using that both functions x and g(x) are continuous, we have that

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{x \to 3} x = 3\end{aligned}\]

and

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{x \to 3} g(x) = g(3) = 2.\end{aligned}\]

Plugin this into the above equality, we find

\[\begin{aligned} 1 = 3 \lim_{x \to 3} f(x) + 2\end{aligned}\]

and hence

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{x \to 3} f(x) = - \frac{1}{3} .\end{aligned}\]

By the first remark above we have

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(3) = - \frac{1}{3}.\end{aligned}\]
